content.text: 1 (a) Define the radian
(i) Calculate the angular speed of the rear wheel
angular speed = \(\mathrm{rad s}^{-1}\)
(ii) Calculate the period of rotation of the small cog
period = s
(iii) Show that the distance moved by point \(X\) on the chain during one full rotation of the small cog is 0.24 m
(iv) Use the information in (b)(iii) to determine the angle through which the large cog rotates during one full rotation of the small cog
angle = rad
(b) The rear wheel and the pedals of a bicycle are connected by a chain that passes around two cogs (toothed wheels), as shown in Fig. 1.1

The small cog has a radius of 0.038 m and is fixed to the rear wheel so that it rotates with it. The large cog has a radius of 0.15 m and is fixed to the pedals so that it rotates with them. The rear wheel has a radius of 0.46 m
The bicycle is being pedalled so that it moves in a straight line at a constant speed of 17 m s-1
(c) The chain of the bicycle in (b) is moved onto a smaller cog fixed to the rear wheel. The speed of the bicycle does not change
Explain, without calculation, the effect of this change on the angular speed of the pedals
2 (a) (i) State what is represented by a gravitational field line
(ii) The Earth may be considered as a uniform sphere, as shown in Fig. 2.1
On Fig. 2.1, draw field lines to represent the Earth's gravitational field outside the Earth
Fig. 2.3 is a copy of Fig. 2.2 without the labels but with two magnetic field lines shown
(i) On Fig. 2.3, label the magnetic poles with the letters N and S to indicate which one is the magnetic N pole and which one is the magnetic S pole
(ii) On Fig. 2.3, draw field lines to represent the Earth's magnetic field outside the Earth
(b) The Earth's magnetic field may be considered as being due to the Earth acting as a long solenoid, as shown in Fig. 2.2
The magnetic poles do not align with the geographic poles, which are on the axis of rotation
(i) Use your answer in (a)(ii) to explain why the observed gravitational field of the Earth does not vary around the surface
(ii) With reference to your answer in (b)(ii), describe how the observed magnetic field of the Earth varies around the surface
(c) An observer moves around the surface of the Earth
3 (a) Define specific heat capacity
(i) Calculate the mass of the block
mass = \(\mathrm{kg}\)
(ii) Show that the volume of the block at a temperature of \(500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is \(3.722 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{3}\)
(iii) Use the information in (b)(ii) to determine the magnitude of the work done on the block when its temperature is raised from \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
(iv) Explain whether the work done on the block is positive or negative
(v) Use the first law of thermodynamics to determine, to three significant figures, a value for the specific heat capacity of aluminium. Explain your reasoning. Give a unit with your answer
specific heat capacity = \(\mathrm{unit}\)
(b) A block of aluminium has a volume of \(3.612 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) at a temperature of \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
Aluminium has a density of \(2.700 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\) at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
It has a density of \(2.620 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\) at \(500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
The block is heated so that its temperature increases from \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) at an atmospheric pressure of \(1.01 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{~Pa}\)
The increase in internal energy of the block is \(4.38 \mathrm{~MJ}\)
(c) Without further calculation, suggest with a reason how doubling the pressure in (b) is likely to affect the answer in (b)(v)
(i) State the meaning, in the equation, of the symbol \(T\)
(ii) Identify the constant \(B\)
4 (a) The equation of state for an ideal gas may be written as
where \(p\) is the pressure of the gas, \(V\) is the volume of the gas, \(A\) is the Avogadro constant, \(B\) is another constant and \(N\) is the number of molecules of the gas
(i) State the meanings, in this equation, of the symbols \(m\) and \(\langle c^{2}\rangle\)
m:
\(\langle c^{2}\rangle\):
(ii) Use the equations in (a) and (b) to derive an expression, in terms of \(A, B\) and \(T\), for the mean kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a molecule of the gas
(b) The product \(p V\) for an ideal gas is also given by
(c) On Fig. 4.1, sketch the variation with \(T\) of the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of the molecules of an ideal gas
5 (a) State what is meant by simple harmonic motion
(i) Calculate the period of the oscillation
period = s
(ii) Determine the amplitude \(x_{0}\) of the oscillation
(iii) Use your answer in (b)(ii) to determine the equation for \(v\) in terms of the displacement \(x\) of the block, where \(v\) is in \(\mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) and \(x\) is in m
(iv) On Fig. 5.1, sketch the variation of \(v\) with \(x\)
(b) A block is suspended by a spring. The block oscillates vertically with simple harmonic motion
The velocity \(v\) of the block varies with time \(t\) according to
where \(v\) is in \(\mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) and \(t\) is in s
(a) On Fig. 6.1, use the symbols \(^+\) and - to indicate which of plates \(X\) and \(Y\) is the positive plate and which is the negative plate
(b) (i) Calculate the electric field strength \(E\) between the plates. Give a unit with your answer
\(E =\) unit
(ii) Determine the acceleration of the electron
acceleration = m s\(^{-2}\)
(i) Show that the minimum wavelength of these electromagnetic waves is 21 pm
(ii) State the region of the electromagnetic spectrum that contains these waves
(iii) Explain how these electromagnetic waves may be used to form images of internal body structures

(c) Many electrons are now accelerated from rest from plate X to plate Y in Fig. 6.1. When the electrons hit plate Y, the absorption of their kinetic energies results in the emission of electromagnetic waves
6 Two parallel metal plates \(X\) and \(Y\) are separated by a distance of 0.041 m , as shown in Fig. 6.1
There is a vacuum between the plates. An electron is at rest at the centre of plate X
A potential difference (p.d.) of 58 kV is applied across the plates. This causes the electron to accelerate towards plate Y
(a) State the relationship between \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\)
(i) the capacitance \(C\), in \(\mu \mathrm{F}\)
(ii) the resistance \(R\), in k
(b) Determine:
7 Fig. 7.1 shows a circuit containing a capacitor of capacitance \(C\) and a resistor of resistance \(R\)
Initially, the switch is open and the potential difference (p.d.) across the capacitor is 12 V
The switch is closed at time \(t=0\) and the capacitor discharges through the resistor

Fig. 7.2 shows the variation of the charge \(Q\) on the capacitor with the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{C}}\) across the capacitor as the capacitor discharges. Fig. 7.3 shows the variation of the current \(I\) in the resistor with the p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) across the resistor as the capacitor discharges
(a) (i) State the type of rectification produced by the circuit of Fig. 8.1
(ii) Calculate \(V_{0}\)
(i) Determine the peak power \(P_{0}\) in the resistor
(ii) On Fig. 8.3, sketch the variation of the power \(P\) in the resistor with \(t\) between \(t=0\) and \(t=2 T\)
(iii) Use the answer in (b)(ii) to explain why the mean power in the resistor is \(\frac{1}{4} P_0\)
(iv) Use the information in (b)(iii) to determine the r.m.s. value of \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\)
r.m.s. voltage = V
(b) Resistor R has resistance \(45 \Omega\)
Assume that there is no p.d. across the diode when it is conducting
8 Fig. 8.1 shows a circuit that produces rectification of an alternating input voltage
The input voltage \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) is sinusoidal. The rectified output voltage \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) is applied across resistor R
The variation of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) with time \(t\) has amplitude \(V_{0}\) and period \(T\), as shown in Fig. 8.2
The root-mean-square (r.m.s.) value of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) is 6.0 V
9 (a) State what is meant by the photoelectric effect
(i) Explain, with reference to photons, why \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) depends on the frequency of the incident electromagnetic radiation
(ii) State three quantitative conclusions that can be drawn from the results in Fig. 9.2 and Fig. 9.3. Use the space for any working
(b) The photoelectric effect is investigated in two stages using the circuit shown in Fig. 9.1
The polished metal plate Y is illuminated with electromagnetic radiation of frequency \(f\) and constant power

In stage 1 of the investigation, frequency \(f\) is set to a constant value of \(2.5 \times 10^{15} \text{Hz}\). The current \(I\) in the ammeter is varied by adjusting the potentiometer P. Fig. 9.2 shows the variation of \(I\) with the voltmeter reading \(V\). There is a value \(V_{\text{S}}\) of \(V\) at which the current just falls to zero

In stage 2 of the investigation, stage 1 is repeated for different values of frequency. As frequency \(f\) is varied, the voltmeter reading \(V_{\text{S}}\) at which the current just falls to zero is measured. Fig. 9.3 shows the variation of \(V_{\text{S}}\) with \(f\)
10 (a) Radioactive decay is a spontaneous process
State the meaning, in this context, of the term spontaneous
(i) Complete Table 10.1 to give expressions, in terms of either or both of \(A\) and \(T\), for the quantities indicated for each of the samples
(ii) Determine, in terms of \(T\), the time at which the two samples will have equal activities
time = \(\mathrm{T}\)
(b) Two radioactive isotopes \(X\) and \(Y\) each decay to form a stable isotope
A sample initially contains only atoms of isotope X. At this time, its activity is 4A
Another sample initially contains only atoms of Y. At this time, its activity is \(A\)
Fig. 10.1 shows the variation of the activity of each sample with time \(t\) between \(t=0\) and \(t=6 T\)
(c) A radiation detector is placed near to one of the samples in (b)
Explain why the count rate measured by the detector is less than the activity of the sample
